caption.p: Influenza virus adaptations that appear to be required for human-to-human transmission.

tr.td: Preference for α2,6-linked mammalian sialic acid receptors over α2,3-linked avian ones (Russell et al., 2006)
HA avoids extracellular inactivation and undergoes conformational changes leading to membrane fusion at appropriate pH for human cells (5.0–5.4 or perhaps 5.5) (Russell, 2014)
Efficient replication in human cells (Cauldwell et al., 2014; Naffakh et al., 2008)
Filamentous morphology associated with several adaptations to mammals (Seladi-Schulman et al., 2014; Seladi-Schulman et al., 2013; Campbell et al., 2014; Beale et al., 2014)
Longer stalk of NA required to penetrate human mucus and deaggregate virions (Blumenkrantz et al., 2013)
Species-specific binding of the NS1 protein to host factors (Rajsbaum et al., 2012)

Substrate selectivity and catalytic rate of NA are calibrated to “balance” avidity of HA for the cell-surface glycan receptor (Zanin et al., 2015; Baum and Paulson, 1991; Yen et al., 2011; Handel et al., 2014)
